items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  5.08
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM: 
Dan Moser, Superintendent
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Call for Nominations to CSBA Delegate Assembly
	 
	 
The California School Boards Association (CSBA) is currently accepting nominations for the CSBA Delegate Assembly.  Any CSBA member board is eligible to nominate board members within their geographical region or subregion.  Boards may nominate as many individuals as it chooses by using the nomination form, which includes obtaining approval from board member(s) being nominated to CSBA's Delegate Assembly.
	 
All nominees must submit a one-page, single-sided, candidate biographical sketch form and an optional one-page, one-sided resume (resume cannot be substituted for the candidate biographical sketch form).  All nominations must be postmarked no later than Friday, January 7, 2012.  Faxes are also acceptable, but must be received by January 9, 2012.  
	 
Delegates serve  two-year terms, beginning April 1, 2012, through March 31, 2014.  There are two required Delegate Assembly meetings each year, one in May in Sacramento and one preceding the CSBA Annual Education Conference and Trade Show in November/December.
	 
	 
	 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Expenses to attend required meetings.
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
General Fund
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommend that the Board of Trustees submit nomination(s) to the CSBA Delegate Assembly.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
	 
Item:  10.02
				 
					 
TO:
Board of Trustees
					 
					 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
					 
					 
PREPARED BY:
Kirsten King, Director of Instructional Services, David Hernandez, CTA Community Committee Outreach Region 1, and Marisa Hanson, ESTA President
SUBJECT:
Public Engagement Project (PEP) Presentation
	 
Public Engagement Project 2009-2011
	 
In 1997, the NEA launched the Public Engagement Program (PEP) to provide state and local NEA affiliates with resources to organize broad-based community dialogues focusing on improving public schools.
	 
In 2009, the California Teachers Association received three Public Engagement Projects from the National Education Association.  The grants awarded to CTA were $10,000.00 per grant for two years to work with districts and the community to look at ways to close the achievement gap.  The grants were awarded to the Alum Rock Educators Association/East Side Teachers Association in San Jose, Merced Teachers Association in Merced, and the Coachella Valley Teachers Association in Coachella.  Each grantee had to commit to go through training and implement as many of the outcomes as possible.
	 
Alum Rock/East Side Project
	 
The Alum Rock/East Side Project brought together educators, administration, and community to look at ways to close the achievement gap between the school age populations of their Districts.  These changes were identified through Community Conversations.  The conversations allowed the community to come together and share their perspective of what they believe can be done in order to improve the educational environment for students, parents and the community.  The project implementation occurs in the following steps:
Initial Sponsoring Committee is trained on what is needed to accomplish their goals.
Community Conversations are implemented to receive input from the community.
The information gathered was reviewed and written into recommendations.
School Board to take action on recommendation.
	 
Recommendations
	 
The Sponsoring Committee believes that, in order for the report to have an impact on the participating schools, the following initial recommendations be approved:
The Public Engagement Project Report is posted on the District's web page. 
The Superintendent forwards the report to the appropriate departments, site administrators and their staff to determine how much of the report's recommendations can be implemented and reported back to the Superintendent and the Board by the end of the school year.
The Year End Final Report is posted on the District's web page to keep the community informed on the status of the implementation of the recommendations.
FISCAL IMPACT:
N/A
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
N/A
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board adopt the sponsoring committee recommendations:
The Public Engagement Project Report is posted on the District's web page. 
The Superintendent forwards the report to the appropriate departments, site administrators and their staff to determine how much of the report's recommendations can be implemented and reported back to the Superintendent and the Board by the end of the school year.
The Year End Final Report is posted on the District's web page to keep the community informed on the status of the implementation of the recommendations.

Dan Moser, Superintendent
PREPARED BY:
Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction and George Sanchez, Coordinator of Student Services
SUBJECT:
Approve Agreement and Adopt Resolution #2011/2012-15 – City of San Jose Mayor’s Gang Prevention Task Force Technical Team Agreement for 2012-2014.
	 
	 
The East Side Union High School District will be providing representatives, Associate Principals of Administrative Services, to attend meetings and trainings, and to participate in the design and implementation of the Strategic Work Plan with members of the City of San Jose Mayor’s Gang Prevention Task Force Technical Team.  East Side Union High School District will collaborate with other members of the Tech Team to the extent possible to meet the goals and carry out the necessary programs of the Work Plan.
	 
All members will comply with the confidentiality laws prescribed in Section 830.1 of the California Welfare and Institutions Code which states that members of a juvenile justice multidisciplinary team engaged in the prevention, identification, and control of crime, including, but not limited to, criminal street gang activity, may disclose and exchange non-privileged information and writings to and with one another relating to any incidents of juvenile crime, including criminal street gang activity, that may also be part of a juvenile court record or otherwise designated as confidential under state law if the member of the team having that information or writing reasonably believes it is generally relevant to the prevention, identification, or control of juvenile crime or criminal street gang activity.  Every member of a juvenile justice multidisciplinary team who receives such information or writings shall be under the same privacy and confidentiality obligations and subject to the same penalties for violating those obligations as the person disclosing or providing  the information or writings.  The team may include, but is not limited, police officers or other law enforcement agents; prosecutors; probation officers; school district personnel or counseling personnel with juvenile crime or criminal street gang control experience or training; state, county, city, or special district recreation specialist with experience or training in juvenile crime or criminal street gang control.  The information obtained shall be maintained in a manner which ensures the protection of confidentiality.
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
None
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
N/A
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the agreement and adopt Resolution #2011/2012-15 authorizing the acceptance of a 2012-2014 Mayor’s Gang Prevention Task Force Technical Team agreement with the City of San Jose.

Item:  11.03
	 
	 
TO:
Board of Trustees
				 
				 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
				 
				 
PREPARED BY:
Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction, and Kirsten King, Director of Instructional Services
				 
				 
SUBJECT:
Approve CAHSEE Local Waivers for Special Education Students
	 
DESCRIPTION:  
Education Code Section 60851 states that students who take one or both parts of the CAHSEE with a modification and receive the equivalent of a passing score are eligible for the waiver request process.  At the request of the student's parent or guardian, a school principal must submit to the local school governing board a request for a waiver of the requirement to pass the part(s) of the CASHEE on which a modification was used and the equivalent of a passing score was earned.  For the local board to waive the CASHEE requirement, the principal must certify to the local board that the pupil has all of the following:
An individualized education program adopted pursuant to the federal Individuals with Disabilities Education Act or a plan adopted pursuant to Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act of 1973 that requires the accommodations or modifications to be provided to the pupil when taking the high school exit examination.
Sufficient high school level coursework either satisfactorily completed or in progress in a high school level curriculum sufficient to have attained the skills and knowledge otherwise needed to pass the high school exit examination.
An individual score report for the pupil showing that the pupil has received the equivalent of a passing score on the high school exit examination measures as determined by the State Board of Education.
The waivers were requested by the school site administration on behalf of the students' parents.
	 
The recommended waivers meet the aforementioned criteria delineated in the Education Code 60851:
Student A
Student B
Student C
Student D
Student E
Student F
Student G
Student H
Student I
Student J
Student K 
				 
	 
FISCAL IMPACT
N/A
	 
FUNDING SOURCE
N/A
	 
RECOMMENDATION
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the recommended waivers.

Attached please find the proposed classified, classified management and certificated administrative holiday schedule for the 2011-2012 school calendar.
CSEA, on behalf of classified employees, and the District have reached a tentative agreement on the holiday schedule and are requesting final approval from the Board of Trustees.  The proposed holiday schedule includes the contractual holidays, plus three additional paid holidays during Christmas break.  It also includes two days during the leave, floating holiday, compensatory time or leave without pay.  This arrangement will enable the District to shutdown all operations during the two-week break, which will result in savings in utility costs.

Item:  12.04
	 
TO:                               Board of Trustees
	 
FROM:                          Dan Moser, Superintendent
	 
PREPARED BY:            Cathy Giammona, Associate Superintendent, Human Resources and Instruction; and         
                                    Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent, Business Services
	 
SUBJECT:                    Approve Job Description and Salary Range for Classified Management Position of
                                    Project Manager
	 
	 
With the start of Measure E Phase II Bond Projects and passage of the Measure G Deferred Maintenance – Capital Fund Projects there is an increased need for a district Project Manager to assist the facilities department with internal coordination and oversight of the district’s Capital Facilities Bond Program.
This position will act as liaison between the district school site administrators, parents and staff, Program Management (SGI) and other consultants, to assure that the Board-authorized projects are accomplished in accordance with District-approved policies and procedures.  
	 
The duties of this position will include monitoring and tracking of project change orders and preventing scope creep while ensuring that the district is represented at site meetings with architects, construction managers, school site administration, and program management (SGI).  In addition, this position will assist with the coordination of capital construction activities including renovations, inspections, contractor and architect meetings, permitting activities, project close-out and building commissioning activities for the purpose of ensuring that all phases of the construction project are completed within specification and with minimal interruption to the school site.
	 
This position is a 12 month Classified Management position at an annual salary range of $70,692 - $90,216.
	 
	 
FUNDING SOURCE:
General Obligation Bond Funds
	 
FISCAL IMPACT:
$70,692 - $90,216.per year
	 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the classified management job description and salary range for the classified management position of Project Manager.

Item:  13.02
TO:
Board of Trustees
							 
FROM:  
							 
Dan Moser, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services, and Karen Poon, Director of Finance
						 
						 
SUBJECT:
Approve First Interim Financial Report for 2011/2012
			 
This is the First of two Interim Reports to be presented to the Governing Board for the 2011-12 fiscal year.  The report provides the Board with the financial status of the district as of October 31, 2011.  This report is presented to the Board to provide the current fiscal status of the district and to meet the fiscal accountability requirements of AB 1200.  
			 
Included in the accompanying binder is an executive summary which summarizes the financial data from the SACS reporting system and budget assumptions that provide the basis for determining the District’s fiscal status.  In addition, there are supporting documentation and comparative analysis of the 2011/12 Adopted Budget vs. First Interim Update as of October 31, 2011, multi-year projections, state reporting forms, and other related documents.  These documents and worksheets serve as tools to certify the ongoing fiscal health of the District for this current year as well as the two subsequent fiscal years.  
			 
California school district revenues and expenditures are subject to constant change.  School district budgets are not static documents, but instead are constantly revised to respond to decisions and actions at the state, local, and federal levels.  The First Interim Report financial projections have been updated to reflect new information received and board actions taken since the Budget was adopted.  
			 
Education Code Section 42131 requires that the Governing Board of each school district certify in writing within 45 days after the close of the period being reported, whether or not the school district is able to meet its financial obligations for the remainder of the fiscal year and subsequent two fiscal years.  The certification is classified as either positive, qualified, or negative.   
			 
Based on the Districts First Interim report and multi-year projections as of October 31, 2011, I am  recommending that the Board approve the attached positive certification for the East Side Union High School District.  Your approval will provide certification to the State ensuring that the District is able to meet its financial obligations for the current fiscal year and subsequent two fiscal years.  
			 
FISCAL IMPACT:
Not Applicable
			 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Not Applicable
			 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the First Interim Financial Report for 2011/2012 as presented.

EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
			 
Item:  13.04
TO:
Board of Trustees
						 
						 
FROM:  
Dan Moser, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services
						 
						 
SUBJECT:
Approve Agreement for Measure E Program Management Services between East Side Union High School District and The Seville Group, Inc. (SGI)
			 
			 
On February 5, 2008 voters of the East Side Union High School District approved Ballot Measure E, authorizing the District to levy up to $349 million for capital construction, consistent with the ballot language. On September 18, 2008, the District entered into a three-year Program Management Services Agreement with the Seville Group, Inc. (SGI).  Prior to the Agreement self-terminating, in its public meeting of September 15, 2011, the Board of Trustees approved a 90 day extension of the Agreement. The intent of this action was to allow adequate time for negotiation of an Amended and Restated Agreement with SGI for ongoing Program Management Services for the Measure E Bond Program.  
			 
Administration has conducted its review and is satisfied with SGI’s performance under this Agreement – as measured by the results achieved in the Measure E Bond Program to date – while concurrently recognizing that this has been a joint endeavor with District Administration and Staff.
			 
During the intervening period, District Administration and Counsel have developed an Amended and Restated Program Management Services Agreement, key attributes of which are outlined, below:
			 
Strictly adheres to District contract guidelines based on the January, 2010 FCMAT review,
Clarifies roles & responsibilities for both SGI and the District, 
Clarifies and enhances indemnification provisions that protect the District,
Provides for 3 one-year periods, subject to annual renewal for a total term of three years, and
Maintains the 5% (not to exceed) fee cap, subject to well defined time & material invoicing.
			 
Subject to Board approval, SGI has reviewed and accepted the Amended and Restated Program Management Services Agreement as presented.
 
FISCAL IMPACT:
2.7 Million
			 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Measure E Bond
			 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees approve the Amended and Restated Agreement for Program Management Services (Measure “E” General Obligation School Facilities Bond Program) between East Side Union High School District and The Seville Group, Inc.

items.item_details:
EAST SIDE UNION HIGH SCHOOL DISTRICT
			 
Item:  14.01
TO:
Board of Trustees
							 
FROM:  
							 
Dan Moser, Superintendent
						 
						 
PREPARED BY:
Marcus Battle, Associate Superintendent of Business Services in Consultation with SGI
						 
						 
SUBJECT:
Approve Update of Measure E Forecast and Spending Plan
			 
			 
At its public meeting of November 17, 2011, the Board of Trustees for the East Side Union High School District considered the Measure E Forecast & Spending Plan and attendant recommendations from staff.  Given limitations on available Measure E Bond funding going forward, the Board evaluated two alternative scenarios through which the District’s Equity Allocation goals could be maximized: 1) moving forward with a limited Phase III focused on closing equity distribution gaps (“Alternative A”) or 2) redressing equity distribution by realigning existing project budgets (“Alternative B”).
			 
The Board indicated a clear preference for the approach articulated as “Alternative A”. The Board directed staff to evaluate options for augmenting an anticipated $90 Million Measure E Bond sale with $20 Million drawn from a combination of the District’s Fund 35 and unallocated Measure G Bond proceeds. The total available funding of $110 Million would result in full realization of “Alternative A”. The Board also directed staff to provide additional information on when this funding augmentation would be required. The accompanying presentation addresses these Board requests for additional information.
			 
			 
FISCAL IMPACT:
$110 Million   
			 
FUNDING SOURCE:
Measure E Bond Proceeds, Fund 35, and Measure G Bond Proceeds
			 
RECOMMENDATION:
It is recommended that the Board of Trustees: 1) Adopt Measure E Bond Program Forecast and Spending Plan, "Alternative A" with a limited Phase III,  2) Authorize staff to proceed with implementation based on total available funds of $110 million, and 3) Ratify augmentation of anticipated $90 million Bond Sale proceeds with $20 million from the following sources: $2 million from current Fund 35 balance, $2 million from Measure G proceeds, $12 million from State matching funds expected in early 2012, and $4 million from State matching funds expected during the next year.
